author: Sam Goldfarb
title: Investors Punish Shares of Companies Most Vulnerable to Rising Rates
text:
Shares of companies with high levels of floating-rate debt are lagging behind the S&P 500, a sign of investor jitters about the financial impact of rising short-term interest rates.
As rates climbed, shares of 50 companies whose floating-rate bonds account for more than 5% of their total debt fell about 4% this year through March 29, according to a report by Goldman Sachs. That is worse than overall indexâ€™s 1% decline in that time.
